articles.headline: A Socially Distanced Las Vegas? What Are the Odds?
articles.snippet: Will a stripped-down version of the city attract the same number of visitors who used to come to party at pools, dance in nightclubs and gamble in casinos?
articles.abstract: Will a stripped-down version of the city attract the same number of visitors who used to come to party at pools, dance in nightclubs and gamble in casinos?
articles.lead_paragraph: For decades, the El Cortez Hotel & Casino in downtown Las Vegas has been known for single-deck blackjack.

articles.headline: HBO Max Is Here to Take On Netflix. Is It Too Late?
articles.snippet: AT&T’s streaming platform goes live on Wednesday. At $15 a month, it’s more expensive than its rivals and comes at a time when household income is dropping.
articles.abstract: AT&T’s streaming platform goes live on Wednesday. At $15 a month, it’s more expensive than its rivals and comes at a time when household income is dropping.
articles.lead_paragraph: HBO has been an innovator for much of its nearly 50-year run. Now, with the unveiling of HBO Max, it’s playing catch-up.

articles.headline: Hunger Program’s Slow Start Leaves Millions of Children Waiting
articles.snippet: Child hunger is soaring, but two months after Congress approved billions to replace school meals, only 15 percent of eligible children had received benefits.
articles.abstract: Child hunger is soaring, but two months after Congress approved billions to replace school meals, only 15 percent of eligible children had received benefits.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As child hunger soars to levels without modern precedent, an emergency program Congress created two months ago has reached only a small fraction of the 30 million children it was intended to help.

articles.headline: Twitter Refutes Inaccuracies in Trump’s Tweets About Mail-In Voting
articles.snippet: Twitter added a link to two of President Trump’s tweets in which he had made false claims about mail-in ballots, urging people to “get the facts.”
articles.abstract: Twitter added a link to two of President Trump’s tweets in which he had made false claims about mail-in ballots, urging people to “get the facts.”
articles.lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — Twitter added information to refute the inaccuracies in President Trump’s tweets for the first time on Tuesday, after years of pressure over its inaction on his false and threatening posts.
articles.byline: By Kate Conger and Davey Alba

articles.headline: Bystander Videos of George Floyd and Others Are Policing the Police
articles.snippet: The initial police account of the death of a Minneapolis man did not mention that an officer’s knee pinned him to the ground. “Please, I can’t breathe,” he said.
articles.abstract: The initial police account of the death of a Minneapolis man did not mention that an officer’s knee pinned him to the ground. “Please, I can’t breathe,” he said.
articles.lead_paragraph: [Follow our live coverage of the protests in Minneapolis over George Floyd’s death.]
articles.byline: By Audra D. S. Burch and John Eligon

articles.headline: An ‘Avalanche of Evictions’ Could Be Bearing Down on America’s Renters
articles.snippet: The economic downturn is shaping up to be particularly devastating for renters, who are more likely to be lower-income and work hourly jobs cut during the pandemic.
articles.abstract: The economic downturn is shaping up to be particularly devastating for renters, who are more likely to be lower-income and work hourly jobs cut during the pandemic.
articles.lead_paragraph: EUCLID, Ohio — The United States, already wrestling with an economic collapse not seen in a generation, is facing a wave of evictions as government relief payments and legal protections run out for millions of out-of-work Americans who have little financial cushion and few choices when looking for new housing.

articles.headline: Larry Kramer, Playwright and Outspoken AIDS Activist, Dies at 84
articles.snippet: He sought to shock the country into dealing with AIDS as a public-health emergency and foresaw that it could kill millions regardless of sexual orientation.
articles.abstract: He sought to shock the country into dealing with AIDS as a public-health emergency and foresaw that it could kill millions regardless of sexual orientation.
articles.lead_paragraph: Larry Kramer, the noted writer whose raucous, antagonistic campaign for an all-out response to the AIDS crisis helped shift national health policy in the 1980s and ’90s, died on Wednesday morning in Manhattan. He was 84.
